elements.content: The hydrothermal reaction of CoCl2·6H2O with cis,cis,cis,cis,cis-1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexane-hexacarboxylic acid (L) generates a unique three-dimensional metal−organic framework (MOF) of [Co3(L-6H)(H2O)6] n (1). X-ray crystallography reveals that each L-6H ligand changes its conformation to a trans,trans,trans,trans,trans form to connect nine Co(II) atoms, and each Co(II) atom is connected to three L-6H ligands, leading to a MOF structure with high symmetry of R3̄. The coexistence of planar and chair-shaped cyclic water hexamers is found in this MOF. Magnetic studies show the occurrence of the field-dependent magnetic transition.
elements.clean_text: The hydrothermal reaction of CoCl2⋅6H2O with cis,cis,cis,cis,cis-1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexane-hexacarboxylic acid (L) generates a unique three-dimensional metal-organic framework (MOF) of [Co3(L-6H)(H2O)6] n  (1). X-ray crystallography reveals that each L-6H ligand changes its conformation to a trans,trans,trans,trans,trans form to connect nine Co(II) atoms, and each Co(II) atom is connected to three L-6H ligands, leading to a MOF structure with high symmetry of R3̄. The coexistence of planar and chair-shaped cyclic water hexamers is found in this MOF. Magnetic studies show the occurrence of the field-dependent magnetic transition.

elements.content: Hydrothermal reaction of 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboylic acid (L), NaOH, 2,2‘-dipyridyl, and CoCl2 results in a novel 3-D metal−organic framework with high symmetry of R3̄. Conformation of the starting reagent was transformed from cis,cis,cis,cis,cis to trans,trans,trans,trans,trans. Each L-6H ligand connects nine Co(II) atoms, and each Co(II) atom is connected to three L-6H ligands. Coexistence of planar and chair-shaped cyclic water hexamers is unprecedentedly observed in this MOF network.
elements.clean_text: Hydrothermal reaction of 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboylic acid (L), NaOH, 2,2‘-dipyridyl, and CoCl2 results in a novel 3-D metal-organic framework with high symmetry of R3̄. Conformation of the starting reagent was transformed from cis,cis,cis,cis,cis to trans,trans,trans,trans,trans. Each L-6H ligand connects nine Co(II) atoms, and each Co(II) atom is connected to three L-6H ligands. Coexistence of planar and chair-shaped cyclic water hexamers is unprecedentedly observed in this MOF network.

elements.content: Great interest has been focused on the rapidly expanding field of hydrogen-bonded water clusters or networks based on the fundamental importance of water in many biological, chemical, and physical processes as well as methane hydrates. So far, structural data of hydrogen-bonded water clusters (such as tetramers, pentamers, hexamers, octamers, and decamers) or polymeric species of chain, tape, or layer structures trapped in metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) as well as in organic molecular crystals are very important for correctly describing the association of water molecules in different surroundings. Of those aggregates, hexamer water species are particularly interesting due to their various conformations including chair, boat, and planar6 forms that have been characterized in MOF or organic crystalline hosts. The planar ring is the basic structural motif found in the ice II structure7 under high pressure and also a prominent structural unit8 in liquid water as determined by computer simulations. Recently, Nauta and Miller detected a quasiplanar hexamer within a helium droplet and found that the lattice of a special crystalline host may offer an environment for stabilizing a higher energy hexamer. Bernal and Bear reported a twist-boat water hexamer, which was one of the possible conformers of “the smallest piece of ice” trapped within channels of a crystal of a dirhodium molecule. However, it is still a challenge how to house or trap water aggregates of special shape in crystal hosts, and much work is required to investigate proper synthetic strategies leading to the desired species. We note that 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylic acid (L), similar to the well-explored 1,4-cyclohexanetdicarboxylic acid and 1,3,5-cyclohexanetricarboxylic acid, is characteristic of multifunctional coordination sites and pH-dependent coordination fashions as well as flexible conformations (Chart ). Although one could anticipate that it will be applied as a versatile ligand in construction of functional MOFs, no report on coordination chemistry of this ligand has been found so far. We report here an interesting MOF structure built from Co(II) and L-6H, in which each L-6H ligand changes its conformation to the trans,trans,trans,trans,trans form and connects nine Co(II) atoms, and each Co(II) atom is connected to three L-6H ligands, leading to a MOF structure with high symmetry of R3̄. Remarkable is both planar and chair-shaped cyclic water hexamers, which are simultaneously trapped in this MOF and are unprecedented.
elements.clean_text: Great interest has been focused on the rapidly expanding field of hydrogen-bonded water clusters or networks based on the fundamental importance of water in many biological, chemical, and physical processes as well as methane hydrates. So far, structural data of hydrogen-bonded water clusters (such as tetramers, pentamers, hexamers, octamers, and decamers) or polymeric species of chain, tape, or layer structures trapped in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as well as in organic molecular crystals are very important for correctly describing the association of water molecules in different surroundings. Of those aggregates, hexamer water species are particularly interesting due to their various conformations including chair, boat, and planar6 forms that have been characterized in MOF or organic crystalline hosts. The planar ring is the basic structural motif found in the ice II structure7 under high pressure and also a prominent structural unit8 in liquid water as determined by computer simulations. Recently, Nauta and Miller detected a quasiplanar hexamer within a helium droplet and found that the lattice of a special crystalline host may offer an environment for stabilizing a higher energy hexamer. Bernal and Bear reported a twist-boat water hexamer, which was one of the possible conformers of "the smallest piece of ice" trapped within channels of a crystal of a dirhodium molecule. However, it is still a challenge how to house or trap water aggregates of special shape in crystal hosts, and much work is required to investigate proper synthetic strategies leading to the desired species. We note that 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylic acid (L), similar to the well-explored 1,4-cyclohexanetdicarboxylic acid and 1,3,5-cyclohexanetricarboxylic acid, is characteristic of multifunctional coordination sites and pH-dependent coordination fashions as well as flexible conformations (Chart ). Although one could anticipate that it will be applied as a versatile ligand in construction of functional MOFs, no report on coordination chemistry of this ligand has been found so far. We report here an interesting MOF structure built from Co(II) and L-6H, in which each L-6H ligand changes its conformation to the trans,trans,trans,trans,trans form and connects nine Co(II) atoms, and each Co(II) atom is connected to three L-6H ligands, leading to a MOF structure with high symmetry of R3̄. Remarkable is both planar and chair-shaped cyclic water hexamers, which are simultaneously trapped in this MOF and are unprecedented.

elements.content: Reaction11 of CoCl2·6H2O, cis,cis,cis,cis,cis-1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboylic acid hydrate (L·H2O), NaOH, 2,2‘-bipyridyl, and water (10 mL) in the molar ratio of 1.5:0.5:1.5:1.0:555 at 175 °C for 60 h yields bright purple crystals of [Co3(L-6H)(H2O)6] n (1) (75%) in single phase. Phase purity of the bulk materials was confirmed by comparison of its powder diffraction pattern with that calculated from the single crystal study (Figure S1, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: Reaction11 of CoCl2⋅6H2O, cis,cis,cis,cis,cis-1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboylic acid hydrate (L⋅H2O), NaOH, 2,2‘-bipyridyl, and water (10 mL) in the molar ratio of 1.5:0.5:1.5:1.0:555 at 175 °C for 60 h yields bright purple crystals of [Co3(L-6H)(H2O)6] n  (1) (75%) in single phase. Phase purity of the bulk materials was confirmed by comparison of its powder diffraction pattern with that calculated from the single crystal study (Figure S1, Supporting Information).

elements.content: Perspective view showing coordination environment (a) and the bridging mode (b) of theL-6H in the structure of 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  Perspective view showing coordination environment (a) and the bridging mode (b) of theL-6H in the structure of 1.

elements.content: X-ray structural analysis12 reveals that 1 crystallizes in rhombohedral R3̄ space group with the asymmetric unit consisting of one-third formula unit, and therefore there is only one crystallographically unique Co(II) atom, which lies in a general position, one unique L-6H ligand which lies across a 3-fold axis, and two aqua ligands. Each cyclohexane ring adopts a chair conformation, similar to that found for L·3H2O. However, all carboxylate groups lie on e-bond positions, suggesting that the conformation of the L-6H ligand (Chart ) was changed from cis,cis,cis,cis,cis of L starting reagent into trans,trans,trans,trans,trans under the hydrothermal condition. Each Co(II) atom is coordinated in an octahedral geometry by four carboxylato O atoms from three L-6H ligands and two trans aqua ligands (Co1−O(carboxylato) = 2.080(4)−2.108(4) Å, Co1−O(aqua) = 2.122(4) and 2.139(4) Å; O(1w)−Co1−O(2w) = 163.24(18)°) (Figure a). Each L-6H ligand connects nine Co(II) atoms through its six carboxylato groups, and each adopts a syn-anti μ2-bridging mode (Figure b). A 3-D MOF structure is therefore generated by the Co-carboxylate coordination (Figure ). Moreover, neglecting the cyclohexane rings from a viewpoint of magnetic superexchange pathway, each Co(II) atom is connected by four syn-anti μ2-carboxylato bridges into a 3-D tetrahedrally connected Co−Co net (Figure S2, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: X-ray structural analysis12 reveals that 1 crystallizes in rhombohedral R3̄ space group with the asymmetric unit consisting of one-third formula unit, and therefore there is only one crystallographically unique Co(II) atom, which lies in a general position, one unique L-6H ligand which lies across a 3-fold axis, and two aqua ligands. Each cyclohexane ring adopts a chair conformation, similar to that found for L⋅3H2O. However, all carboxylate groups lie on e-bond positions, suggesting that the conformation of the L-6H ligand (Chart ) was changed from cis,cis,cis,cis,cis of L starting reagent into trans,trans,trans,trans,trans under the hydrothermal condition. Each Co(II) atom is coordinated in an octahedral geometry by four carboxylato O atoms from three L-6H ligands and two trans aqua ligands (Co1-O(carboxylato) = 2.080(4)-2.108(4) Å, Co1-O(aqua) = 2.122(4) and 2.139(4) Å; O(1w)-Co1-O(2w) = 163.24(18)°) (Figure a). Each L-6H ligand connects nine Co(II) atoms through its six carboxylato groups, and  each adopts a syn-anti μ2-bridging mode (Figure b). A 3-D MOF structure is therefore generated by the Co-carboxylate coordination (Figure ). Moreover, neglecting the cyclohexane rings from a viewpoint of magnetic superexchange pathway, each Co(II) atom is connected by four syn-anti μ2-carboxylato bridges into a 3-D tetrahedrally connected Co-Co net (Figure S2, Supporting Information).

elements.content: View of the 3-D coordination network along thec-axis in the structure of 1.
elements.clean_text: 2  View of the 3-D coordination network along thec-axis in the structure of 1.

elements.content: Remarkably, two types of cyclic water hexamers of (12) in chair and planar conformation (Figure a,b), respectively, are unambiguously trapped within the 3-D MOF structure of 1. The chair hexamer is formed by hydrogen-bonding between the symmetry-related O1w atoms (O1w···O1w = 2.834(2) Å; O1w−H1wb···O1w = 175(3)°). Each chair hexamer further donates six hydrogen bonds with symmetry-related O4 atoms (O1w···O4a = 2.746(3) Å; O1w−H1wa···O4a = 159(3)°). Planar hexamer is from hydrogen-bonded symmetry-related O2w (O2w···O2w = 3.101(2) Å; O2w−H2wb···O2w = 174(4)°). It should be noted that the O···O distance in the chair ring is significantly longer than that (O···O 2.85 Å) in liquid water. It seems to represent attempts of the water to fit into a cavity that is too large for it. Each planar hexamer also donates six hydrogen bonds with symmetry-related O1 atoms (O2w···O1g = 2.876(3) Å; O2w−H2wa···O1g = 174(3)°). Noteworthy is that each planar hexamer is connected to six chair hexamers via the Co−water coordination (Figure c), and also each chair hexamer is connected to six planar hexamers via the Co−water coordination. Therefore, an unique high-symmetry 3-D Co−water net is generated (Figure d,e). It should be also noted that coexistence of planar and chair-shaped cyclic water hexamers in the same MOF structure is unprecedented. A rare comparable example was recently found in 1,4-[B(HO)2]2C6H4·4H2O that contains hexameric units in chair and boat conformations, indicating a contribution to the structural elucidation of bulk water.
elements.clean_text: Remarkably, two types of cyclic water hexamers of   (12) in chair and planar conformation (Figure a,b), respectively, are unambiguously trapped within the 3-D MOF structure of 1. The chair hexamer is formed by hydrogen-bonding between the symmetry-related O1w atoms (O1w⋅⋅⋅O1w = 2.834(2) Å; O1w-H1wb⋅⋅⋅O1w = 175(3)°). Each chair hexamer further donates six hydrogen bonds with symmetry-related O4 atoms (O1w⋅⋅⋅O4a = 2.746(3) Å; O1w-H1wa⋅⋅⋅O4a = 159(3)°). Planar hexamer is from hydrogen-bonded symmetry-related O2w (O2w⋅⋅⋅O2w = 3.101(2) Å; O2w-H2wb⋅⋅⋅O2w = 174(4)°). It should be noted that the O⋅⋅⋅O distance in the chair ring is significantly longer than that (O⋅⋅⋅O 2.85 Å) in liquid water. It seems to represent attempts of the water to fit into a cavity that is too large for it. Each planar hexamer also donates six hydrogen bonds with symmetry-related O1 atoms (O2w⋅⋅⋅O1g = 2.876(3) Å; O2w-H2wa⋅⋅⋅O1g = 174(3)°). Noteworthy is that each planar hexamer is connected to six chair hexamers via the Co-water coordination (Figure c), and also each chair hexamer is connected to six planar hexamers via the Co-water coordination. Therefore, an unique high-symmetry 3-D Co-water net is generated (Figure d,e). It should be also noted that coexistence of planar and chair-shaped cyclic water hexamers in the same MOF structure is unprecedented. A rare comparable example was recently found in 1,4-[B(HO)2]2C6H4⋅4H2O that contains hexameric units in chair and boat conformations, indicating a contribution to the structural elucidation of bulk water.

elements.content: Perspective views showing the chair (a) and coplanar (b) cyclic water hexamer units, the connectivity between the coplanar and coplanar units (c), and the 3-D Co−water net via the metal coordination along thec-axis (d) and a-axis (e) in 1.
elements.clean_text: 3  Perspective views showing the chair (a) and coplanar (b) cyclic water hexamer units, the connectivity between the coplanar and coplanar units (c), and the 3-D Co-water net via the metal coordination along thec-axis (d) and a-axis (e) in 1.

elements.content: Schematic Presentation of theL-6H Ligand in cis,cis,cis,cis,cis- (a) and trans,trans,trans,trans,trans-conformations (b)
elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Presentation of theL-6H Ligand in cis,cis,cis,cis,cis- (a) and trans,trans,trans,trans,trans-conformations (b)

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility of 1 was measured in the range of 2−300 K at 10 kOe. The χ(T) data between 50 and 300 K was fit to a modified Curie−Weiss Law, χ(T) = χ0 + C/(T − θ) with a Weiss constant, θ = −27.73 K, and a Curie constant, C = 2.99 cm3 mol-1 K (Figure S3, Supporting Information), indicating a significant antiferromagnetic coupling between the Co(II) S = 3/2 spins through the syn-anti carboxylato bridges. According to the 3-D net connectivity, only one effective magnetic exchange pathway is present within the net via syn-anti μ2-carboxylato bridges. The room temperature effective magnetic moment value per Co(II) ion, defined as μeff = 2.83C 1/2, is 4.89 μB for 1, which is significant higher than the excepted spin-only value (3.87 μB) due to the orbital contribution of the Co(II) ion.
elements.clean_text: The magnetic susceptibility of 1 was measured in the range of 2-300 K at 10 kOe. The χ(T) data between 50 and 300 K was fit to a modified Curie-Weiss Law, χ(T) = χ0 + C/(T  - θ) with a Weiss constant, θ = -27.73 K, and a Curie constant, C = 2.99 cm3 mol-1 K (Figure S3, Supporting Information), indicating a  significant antiferromagnetic coupling between the Co(II) S = 3/2 spins through the syn-anti carboxylato bridges. According to the 3-D net connectivity, only one effective magnetic exchange pathway is present within the net via syn-anti μ2-carboxylato bridges. The room temperature effective magnetic moment value per Co(II) ion, defined as μeff = 2.83C 1/2, is 4.89 μB for 1, which is significant higher than the excepted spin-only value (3.87 μB) due to the orbital contribution of the Co(II) ion.

elements.content: The magnetic behaviors of 1 are further characterized by temperature- and field-dependent measurements at low temperature. The magnetization maximum disappears at or above 15 kOe (Figure a), indicating that the antiferromagnetic interactions are overcome by the external field. These features are the characteristics of metamagnetic behaviors, which are further confirmed by the field dependence of magnetization (Figure b). The field-cooled (FC) magnetization at 20 Oe shows the appearance of a sharp peak at ca. 3.0 K (Figure S4, Supporting Information), suggesting the occurrence of a long-range antiferromagnetic ordering.
elements.clean_text: The magnetic behaviors of 1 are further characterized by temperature- and field-dependent measurements at low temperature. The magnetization maximum disappears at or above 15 kOe (Figure a), indicating that the antiferromagnetic interactions are overcome by the external field. These features are the characteristics of metamagnetic behaviors, which are further confirmed by the field dependence of magnetization (Figure b). The field-cooled (FC) magnetization at 20 Oe shows the appearance of a sharp peak at ca. 3.0 K (Figure S4, Supporting Information), suggesting the occurrence of a long-range antiferromagnetic ordering.

elements.content: χM (per Co) vs T plot at different external fields (a) and field-dependent magnetization (b) of 1 at different temperature.
elements.clean_text: 4  χM (per Co) vs T plot at different external fields (a) and field-dependent magnetization (b) of 1 at different temperature.

elements.content: The thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1 under an atmospheric environment shows an onset of water loss at higher temperatures above 155 °C and the 3-D MOF begins to decompose above 345 °C (Figure S5, Supporting Information). The first weight loss of 17.1% from 160 to 310 °C is in accordance with the loss of two coordinated water molecules per Co (calculated:  17.2%), while the second weight loss corresponds to the removal of all the organic components to yield Co3O4 (found:  37.3%; calculated:  38.4%). Two endothermic peaks (310, 350 °C) in the DTA curve also record the weight loss processes of various groups.
elements.clean_text: The thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1 under an atmospheric environment shows an onset of water loss at higher temperatures above 155 °C and the 3-D MOF begins to decompose above 345 °C (Figure S5, Supporting Information). The first weight loss of 17.1% from 160 to 310 °C is in accordance with the loss of two coordinated water molecules per Co (calculated: 17.2%), while the second weight loss corresponds to the removal of all the organic components to yield Co3O4 (found: 37.3%; calculated: 38.4%). Two endothermic peaks (310, 350 °C) in the DTA curve also record the weight loss processes of various groups.

elements.content: In summary, we have synthesized an interesting 3-D cobalt (II) coordination network of 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboylate. Magnetic studies reveal that 1 exhibits spontaneous magnetic ordering and magnetic transition. Detailed magnetic investigations on 1 and other complexes15 are underway.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have synthesized an interesting 3-D cobalt (II) coordination network of 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboylate. Magnetic studies reveal that 1 exhibits spontaneous magnetic ordering and magnetic transition. Detailed magnetic investigations on 1 and other complexes15 are underway.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic files in CIF format, a plot showing Co−Co net connectivity, simulated and experimental PXRD data, solid-state EPR spectrum measured at 9 K, plots of χΜ Τ and χΜ -1 (inset) for 1 at 10 kOe, temperature dependence of the field-cooled and zero-field-cooled magnetization, and TG data for 1. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text:
Supporting Information Available 

X-ray crystallographic files in CIF format, a plot showing Co-Co net connectivity, simulated and experimental PXRD data, solid-state EPR spectrum measured at 9 K, plots of χΜ Τ and χΜ -1 (inset) for 1 at 10 kOe, temperature dependence of the field-cooled and zero-field-cooled magnetization, and TG data for 1. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content: Reaction11 of CoCl2·6H2O, cis,cis,cis,cis,cis-1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboylic acid hydrate (L·H2O), NaOH, 2,2‘-bipyridyl, and water (10 mL) in the molar ratio of 1.5:0.5:1.5:1.0:555 at 175 °C for 60 h yields bright purple crystals of [Co3(L-6H)(H2O)6] n (1) (75%) in single phase. Phase purity of the bulk materials was confirmed by comparison of its powder diffraction pattern with that calculated from the single crystal study (Figure S1, Supporting Information).

Phase purity of the bulk materials was confirmed by comparison of its powder diffraction pattern with that calculated from the single crystal study (Figure S1, Supporting Information).

cln_elements.content:
The magnetic susceptibility of 1 was measured in the range of 2−300 K at 10 kOe. The χ(T) data between 50 and 300 K was fit to a modified Curie−Weiss Law, χ(T) = χ0 + C/(T − θ) with a Weiss constant, θ = −27.73 K, and a Curie constant, C = 2.99 cm3 mol-1 K (Figure S3, Supporting Information), indicating a significant antiferromagnetic coupling between the Co(II) S = 3/2 spins through the syn-anti carboxylato bridges. According to the 3-D net connectivity, only one effective magnetic exchange pathway is present within the net via syn-anti μ2-carboxylato bridges. The room temperature effective magnetic moment value per Co(II) ion, defined as μeff = 2.83C 1/2, is 4.89 μB for 1, which is significant higher than the excepted spin-only value (3.87 μB) due to the orbital contribution of the Co(II) ion.

The thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1 under an atmospheric environment shows an onset of water loss at higher temperatures above 155 °C and the 3-D MOF begins to decompose above 345 °C (Figure S5, Supporting Information). The first weight loss of 17.1% from 160 to 310 °C is in accordance with the loss of two coordinated water molecules per Co (calculated:  17.2%), while the second weight loss corresponds to the removal of all the organic components to yield Co3O4 (found:  37.3%; calculated:  38.4%). Two endothermic peaks (310, 350 °C) in the DTA curve also record the weight loss processes of various groups.

According to the 3-D net connectivity, only one effective magnetic exchange pathway is present within the net via syn-anti μ2-carboxylato bridges. The room temperature effective magnetic moment value per Co(II) ion, defined as μeff = 2.83C 1/2, is 4.89 μB for 1, which is significant higher than the excepted spin-only value (3.87 μB) due to the orbital contribution of the Co(II) ion. 

The thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1 under an atmospheric environment shows an onset of water loss at higher temperatures above 155 °C and the 3-D MOF begins to decompose above 345 °C (Figure S5, Supporting Information). The first weight loss of 17.1% from 160 to 310 °C is in accordance with the loss of two coordinated water molecules per Co (calculated: 17.2%), while the second weight loss corresponds to the removal of all the organic components to yield Co3O4 (found: 37.3%; calculated: 38.4%). Two endothermic peaks (310, 350 °C) in the DTA curve also record the weight loss processes of various groups.

metadata.title:
Coexistence of Planar and Chair-Shaped Cyclic Water Hexamers in a Unique
Cyclohexanehexacarboxylate-Bridged Metal−Organic Framework
